title: Serious Talk: People need to chill out about the Balance Team
body:
The fact that one of the posts at the top of the boards is that riot's balancing team needs to be changed is just sad.

Did they overbuff Galio? Yes. They've also given their thoughts on why they went through with it and to be honest, I can understand their mentality.

I *HATE* that despite how many wins the balance team achieves, they're still told they're shit at their job.

The balance team is great, and has done a fantastic job of trying to balance this game and flesh it out.

And before someone whips out the ardent censor fiasco, ardent censor was buffed in 7.2 and wasn't changed for a long time before it became "op".

To everyone reading this thread that disagrees, grow up already. If you want change, you don't bitch and whine. You have a goddamn civil conversation with actual reasoning.

Edit: Just a sidenote, but I think it's super interesting how split this thread is. It wasn't downvoted into oblivion because so many people are combating it by upvoting it.

replies.body:
"I HATE that despite how many wins the balance team achieves, they're still told they're shit at their job."
Some champions were left in the gutter because their kits were too toxic to let get a foothold, other items were left sub-par because some champions would benefit way too much from it, ext. 
Yet they make such drastic changes anyway, only to post a few patches later about how the result was unexpected. 
I agree nobody wants to be berated for their employment, but somethings should require common sense &/or forethought. The pbe used to be for balance checking, but for recent years they just use it for skin advertising.

Gameplay boards need to be heavily changed if we ever want Riot to dare coming on here and discuss the game with us.

This board brings out the worst of our community and is usually just hatemongering or salty posts.

The first step would be splitting gameplay into three categories:
Design (Is X champion/item doing stuff he's supposed to, does X champion need a rework, etc.)
Live game (What issues do we currently face in the game)
Q'n'A, Guides (How do I play X champion/against X champion)

No, the riot employees should comment or respond to threads and such regardless if people are being civil. They are a fucking company, thay should be able to take constructive critiaism, not fucking only reply when people are praising the shit out of them.It just shows how sensitive they are.

> No, the riot employees should comment or respond to threads and such regardless if people are being civil. They are a fucking company, thay should be able to take constructive critiaism, not fucking only reply when people are praising the shit out of them.It just shows how sensitive they are.

Constructive criticism, yes. Proclaiming that they needto be fired and are absolute crap at their job, no. There’s a difference between the two.

The first is more like, I disagree with this and here are solid reasons why.

The second can be seen in one of the top board posts like what the OP referred to.

Constructive criticism and true discussion allows rioters to participate more, while the calling for jobs just makes them not comment. They might read, but they won’t interact much because that thread had by that time become such a Riot balance hate thread that there would be little to no real discussion to be had.

It's also the fact that engaging in why we are keeping our jobs is taking time away from improving the things that made the original rage thread occur in the first place. As a lead playtester my priority currently is not to justify to the internet that I understand LoL; it's to figure out the holes or events in our processes that allowed Galio to happen in the first place.

> [{quoted}](name=penguin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=abZrqEHd,comment-id=000d000000000000,timestamp=2017-10-26T23:17:50.234+0000)
>
> It's also the fact that engaging in why we are keeping our jobs is taking time away from improving the things that made the original rage thread occur in the first place. As a lead playtester my priority currently is not to justify to the internet that I understand LoL; it's to figure out the holes or events in our processes that allowed Galio to happen in the first place.

I think letting something like Galio through indicates that there isn't enough consideration about abuse cases that are not necessarily strong strictly looking at winrate or counterplay, but are game ruining when they are executed successfully.

Like what if you have a champion who wins hard 50% of games, so dominant that opponents feel like they can't play the game, but in the other 50% of games the champion is irrelevant and it's a free win for their opponents. You have 5 players not enjoying the game every single game this champion is played. In the first case it's the opponents playing against it, and in the second case it's the guy playing it + his team who are effectively in a 4v5.

I honestly feel like Riot's design team doesn't think about this concept anymore. It was championed by Zileas back in the day but it seems like it was forgotten and this Galio change making it to live is one of the most egregious symptoms of this problem.

This is a concept that we are and have been stressing in Playtest onboarding for as long as I've been here (~1.5 years). We slipped on Galio, but will be further prioritizing/emphasizing destructive testing in the future.

Has any rioter ever suggested to just wipe PBE clean, make a new PBE boards and just create new rules for keeping a PBE account active? 

So only players that are willing to test the game a give feedback are allowed, thus creating somewhere where Rito can look for somewhat reliable feedback, instead of PBE just be a youtuber's showcase video goldmine, or skin preview?

Watch speed runners. The amount of insane glitches triggered by the most ridiculous things (There's a Ratchet & Clank speed run that has a crucial glitch based on jumping at a specific corner of a wall over and over until it triggers) that are ALWAYS in games released to commercial sale is astronomical. It is not humanly possible to find everything and even once released it can take months before an abusive build or trick is found.

This is not something about Riot, it's something all game developers do and it isn't because of laziness, it's because you cannot expect people to be able to account for every single possibility. Riot is not Batman.

{{champion:31}} ? After a dozen of buffs, he was forcefully inserted into the meta.

{{champion:15}} ? Hotnerfed within hours.

{{champion:40}} ? Hotnerfed twice within 2 days after 7.19 went live.

{{champion:3}} ? Hotnerfed 3 days after.

{{champion:113}}  rework? Hotnerfed within hours.

{{item:3190}} +{{item:3107}}  took months to nerf despite how broken the combination was. It got to a point where {{champion:90}}{{champion:143}} were building it.

{{item:3504}}  took nearly 3 months of Solo Queue abuse to get nerfed.

Release {{champion:164}} ? How was she allowed to get released in that state?

{{item:3134}} took months to get nerfed into the ground.

{{champion:154}}  became a balance mess ever since his rework.

If there were few problems, it would be fine. But the fact that so many things got overbuffed (I am certain I forget a lot of other things) shows that there can be internal problems in testing new stuff.

Sorry to be fair to riot: Even the community (atleast the majority of what i read) said "camille is so shit and garbage BUFF HER" the same they said about zacs rework and we both know how that turned out. 
As much as i like to give riot some flack we do have to be fair about these cases when the community sometimes is even more idiotic in what they say. 
Current eve is the same. She is very strong and i do believe that riot will have big problems with her kit in the future while boards is all "EVE IS SO GARBAGE OMFG UNPLAYABLE".

I don't think I ever saw someone express that Camille was weak? 

She was nerfed twice before even leaving the PBE.

Isn't engaging with the community part of the job, though?  I mean if you really want your fingers on the pulse of what the community wants, you have to engage.  Frankly, your aloof attitude points to the problem - you view engaging with people in the community as a bother instead of a learning experience.  Sure, you can rightly ignore the vitriol rage posts, but to flat out ignore constructive feedback for years on end is why people are so hateful now.  It's cause and effect, and you just pointed to the actual issue when you say engaging with the community is a distraction.  You cannot be surprised when people are upset if this is how you see us 

And Galio is hardly the first big mistake you guys have made lately.  Let's not pretend that Ardent Censor, Janna, Camille, Cho, and many other issues haven't been a problem in just your tenure.  

The flak is earned.  I'm not saying the blind rage is okay, but the abundance of frustration is.

> Isn't engaging with the community part of the job, though? I mean if you really want your fingers on the pulse of what the community wants, you have to engage. Frankly, your aloof attitude points to the problem - you view engaging with people in the community as a bother instead of a learning experience. 

I don't view engaging with the community as a bother at all -- I very much value talking to people here or on Reddit. I was just providing an explanation for what can be a frustrating silent experience for players. As a player people often think that Rioter silence means that we are completely ignoring the problem, when in reality it's often the exact opposite. We can show up to happy shitposts and meme threads any time things are going well, but whenever something is on fire it'd be silly to spend too much time on forums or reddit when we should be putting out said fire.

I would never want us to stop getting flak; that would mean players aren't holding us accountable! I'm not thin-skinned.

This is honestly the FIRST response I've ever gotten from a Rioter, and I've been posting and playing since Season 3.  It's beyond frustrating when people express their concerns, display proof of concept (videos of AP Galio one-shotting, videos of pros playing Camille on PBE, etc) just to have said issues still make their way through to live servers unscathed.  

And as a support main being forced to play Ardent supports for over a month on end, I can tell you that the radio silence is more than just a little infuriating.  Variety was sacrificed for a concept that we were never really made to understand.  

I do appreciate you taking the time to respond.  It was a pleasant surprise.  And the reason why people get so heated is because we LOVE this game.  We want to see the game thrive for years to come, but we also want Rioters to be engaged and listen to our concerns.  If it hasn't been a meme or a name change, or perhaps a splash art, Riot hasn't listened or implemented much of our concerns into the game.  PBE is all but disregarded, even when it provides proof of concept.

> I do appreciate you taking the time to respond. It was a pleasant surprise. And the reason why people get so heated is because we LOVE this game. We want to see the game thrive for years to come, but we also want Rioters to be engaged and listen to our concerns.

I understand that completely, during my interview process I said that unfiltered, non-bullshit community interaction was one of the biggest draws for me to Riot as a player. I hope to improve and that Playtest leads the way forward when it comes to talking to you guys :). Stop by patch chat every chat and hold us accountable when we mess up!
And the holes that allowed Sivir, Janna, and Singed to happen, to use just a few examples from recent months?  Or is it the same problem that hasn’t been fixed?

> figure out the holes or events in our processes that allowed Galio to happen in the first place.

I've got an idea. You literally didn't even look at the numbers.

Fact is, you all never do. Locket and Redemption is broken as fuck but you don't even do the math to figure that out.

I clearly repeat, "If you don't do your job, then you should be fired. There is no excuse for the level of bias, ignorance, and incompetence presented in the past 2 years." You can disagree, but then I expect a counterargument to why.

Exactly. 
In every other market section people DO get fired for incompetence, bias and various other reasons if they fail their job but somehow in the gaming industry it is totally okay and should never be called out. 
If it is NOT incompetence or ignorence but pure purpose than riot should have the decency to atleast be honest about it.

Have you guys at riot considered offering possible playtesting oppurtunities to the members of our community such as https://www.youtube.com/user/Vandiril that find these incredibly over the top builds that break parts of the game regularly? I think it would be good to consider it.

I know when I first read the patch notes, I wasn't thinking about "omg full AP galio is going to be busted!", I thought "Huh, that should make 1-2 damage item bruiser galio pretty good." It's possible you guys have a lot of people who are more like me, where we think about the way a champ is ideally made to be played, and not the absurd on either end of tankyness or damage.

That out there, I am glad that you play testers are as thorough as you are. I'm sure there are a LOT of internal changes that are tested that never see the light of day to be criticized in the first place.

I feel it might help if there were more Rioters whose job was specifically to communicate with the playerbase. It's a very honorable intention to want designers, engineers, playtesters, artists, and so on come directly to the Boards and share with the players, but in the end it constantly feels like whenever a Rioter takes the time to come here, they're taking time out from their real job, or are doing so in their own spare time. This I think is a major reason why communication between Riot and the playerbase feels so spotty at times, and it's all the more unfortunate that it makes some players direct blame at individual Rioters, who really are doing the best they can. I feel player communication needs to be recognized as a real, full-time job alongside the rest, and given its own dedicated resources and employees, as maintaining good relations with players is important and cannot simply be delegated to Rioters who already have busy, intense work hours to begin with.

Rioter's responses fall under three categories.

1: Is it a bug with a skin or store related.

2: Is it complimenting riot in any sense of the word.

3: is it under the memes & games category.


If it hits under any of these criteria they will most likely respond. I would like a way to know if a rioter visited a post not just when they comment it could be extremely helpful to know they are seeing are issues without necessarily without having to comment, for example a well thought post of why AP Galio is op and needs nerfs ( I know he is being hotfixed) and then the one's that are "OMFG GALIO OP NERF HIM INTO OBLIVION THAT IS ALL" that deserve to be ignored to an extent.

Posts like the ones you mention are why Rioters practically give up on communicating and interacting on the Gameplay boards.

Posts like the one you made are why they haven't given up entirely.

I mean, a post doesn't need to be positive for a Rioter to respond to it. It just needs to be reasonable. 

Hyperbole and personal attacks make a post fall outside of "reasonable" to me - if I see that it says to me "this person does not want to have a discussion, they want a head on a spike". Like, the hard part is always that we have to weigh the time we spend talking on Boards with time doing work. 

So if it looks like the main thing a topic wants to do is shout at someone well, honestly, you get that with or without a Rioter response. If it looks like a player wants to *actually* talk about a specific topic or I have an answer to a reasonable question they've asked then it's like yeah me posting here will actually add something! 

But like, also just know that we read everything on Boards (and sometimes that's hard tbh) even if we don't respond.

Personally, I don't need a single thing justified. I've been around since after Zac was released, shortly before Lissandra came out. And I've followed the red tracker nigh-religiously, always interested in seeing what you guys have to say. What your perspective is, the reasoning, and your plans. I'm well aware you guys watch and read the boards closely, but have no interest in sacrificing yourselves just to temporarily appease bloodthirsty lynch mobs.

You guys love and care about not just this game but also its community, for better or worse. And I'm honestly proud to support it and keep playing, knowing that even if you guys fall short or make a mistake, every action you guys take is with the intent of making the game more enjoyable and interesting. Even when that makes things hard for a filthy Kha main like me (Season 3/4 nerfs anybody?)

My one wish is that it would be easier to share ideas or know when's the best chance to get a rioter response. I posted a (semi- at least) detailed concept for reworking crit chance, and while it's gotten a few views not a single feedback post to be found. From anybody. It's pretty demoralizing Dx

First of all, I think I have some dust in my eye from your second paragraph. We seriously do try our best because we love this game and this community. Second, I agree with your feedback.  

Chances are someone here at Riot saw your post, but I feel like often what you need is the right person. Like, I read a ton of topics (I am guilty of Boards-ing in my time off lol) from all Boards categories but I don't usually respond unless I know something about the topic. I'm also not more likely to read topics with "Riot" in the title or highly upvoted topics, honestly. Personally, I'm slightly more focused on the Gameplay section but that's because that's the area I work in and am most likely to be able to answer Qs/discuss in (when I worked on the mobile app I was more active in that section etc). 

I try to point other Rioters who have more subject matter expertise to topics I see but sometimes I don't know who to even point or, even if I do, that Rioter might be busy or forget or a million other things. If a Rioter has put out an answer (and I know about it), I do my best to at least link to that answer (which is like, a lot of "ifs" when you think about it). 

But when it comes down to it you probably don't want to talk to me about crit - I have opinions but they're pretty rudimentary.  Ideally, you'd want a game designer who has actually worked in that area or someone with in depth stat knowledge to speak to you about it. Making that connection with specific experts is the hard part. :/ 

TL;DR I agree that I wish it was easier to connect Rioters with relevant knowledge to the right player topics, and I think it's a hard challenge. There's no magic bullet to get a relevant Rioter to see your topic.

To be fair though, I can understand where some people's frustrations with the balance team comes from. Riot has made a lot of questionable balance changes within in the last few months. Like Ardent's "nerf" that actually still kept its strength, Janna's "nerf" that made her win rate skyrocket, not addressing or even acknowledging balance problems through the entire season (AKA Twitch), Maokai, Sejuani and Zac's update, overtuning Cho etc.

This isn't to say that they haven't done good things.
Riot circle jerk thread. The balance team was ass this season, it is painfully obvious.
Agreed. I don't like bashing the people that balance this game, given my love for it, but they were NOT "on top of the game" in terms of Balance this season. They came off as very lazy. ):

I would agree with you, but seeing that Season 7 was an absolute disaster in terms of balancing the game should not be overlooked.  It starts off with Camille and later Ivern being broken for patches on end, lethality overbuffed, the tank update (Zac and Sej broken), consistently buffing ADCs and their items while ignoring the need for diversity in the mid lane through new AP items, Cho'Gath buffed time and time again to force him into the meta as a bursty tank (why tho?),Ardent censor broken for multiple patches, and now buffing Galio's AP ratios through the roof for, honestly, no logical reason, should not reprieve them of criticism. 

 If anything, I hope this criticism forces them to understand more about how the game works and what they should do in testing to make sure that things are not seriously overpowered before releasing them; this season, they were so naive... I mean seriously... what a blunder of a season! Either way, I'm looking forward to them learning from these mistakes to make Season 8 much more enjoyable than the previous.

This is a massive egregious error though, I'll deal with some things but this was flat out preventable or at the very least they should have hotfixed or disabled him after everyone across all elos basically told them in many different ways that it was not an ok change and was in fact gamebreakingly broken.

This fiasco was just a slap to the face and I honestly believe they should be embarrassed it got to this point and as well offer us, the community, a public apology and assurance they'll work better in the future towards something like this not happening again.

I saw a whopping 1 thread saying anything as mean as that they should be fired. A couple stray posts perhaps inside other threads, but fairly rare, and not upvote fests. Mostly I've seen a bunch of threads going "holy hell how did this go live?!" and I think that's absolutely deserved. One thread calling for firing doesn't warrant a whole other thread telling people to chill about it.

I knew the Galio changes weren't ok by just reading them. I saw it first hand clear as day on the first game I saw it in action, and I was the one playing it. It felt extremely unfair and overpowered by mid game. Every game I've seen Galio since then has shown it to be disgustingly obviously broken.

The real key here is that _even if the changes lowered Galio's win rate, they would have not been ok because they create unhealthy gameplay._ The initial change feels more like a bug than an intentional change. How little playtesting had to happen for that to go live? They _knew_ it was a big increase in damage, they _knew_ there was already a lot of concern from players and tales of it being ridiculous, and yet it still not only went live but such concerns were met with what felt like shrugged shoulders. I saw several Rioters comment on it and no one seemed concerned or even cautious. And then to top it all off... it took them too long to fix it.

I would be less shocked and annoyed at a seemingly small change that ended up having a big effect. At least then there'd be justification for the ramifications being missed in testing. But this was _big, obvious, clearly in need of more than a couple games of testing_ and so I assume it got more than that, yet somehow went live.

Agree 100%. Yes, Galio's balancing is really off. Yes, there have been similarly large and seemingly obvious balance issues in the past. For sure, the balance team does likely deserve some criticism for how some issues aren't anticipated well enough, or allowed to persist for too long. None of this, however, provides _any_ justification for calling any member of Riot to be fired. Everyone makes mistakes, and seeing how League is a) an incredibly complex game that is b) on the verge of one of the biggest balance upsets in its history, yet is c) still largely functional, I'd say the balance team is doing a pretty damn good job. It is always easier to criticize than it is to do anything, and while it may be understandable for players to be frustrated at the game's current state of affairs, instinctively lashing out at other people is _not_ the way to bring about anything constructive.

Speaking of constructive, as several other players have mentioned, posts calling for Rioters to be fired are _exactly_ the kind of shit that pushes them away from the Boards. When I was on the Warden team, I met a member of Riot who took it upon herself to _personally convince Rioters to post on the Boards_, simply because of how much they did not feel like going on here. When I asked her what the major problem was, she told me it was the toxic atmosphere and the baseless personal attacks against the developers. Calls to fire Rioters and similar bullshit are a prime reason why Gameplay is still not the healthy communication space between players and Riot that we've hoped for, and the users making those posts are simply making things worse for themselves and for others. 

While at this point it's already too late, I really think the "balance team needs to be changed" thread needs to be removed, as with any other thread like it. As long as it stays up, it conveys the message to everyone that it's okay to personally attack members of Riot, and thereby drive them away from Gameplay, and will continue to spawn more terrible threads like it. No matter how good the actual content in the OP is, that is something that can be posted in a thread with a less inflammatory title.

No one is complaining because he got buffed.

People are complaining because what made it to live should have been changed in the first day of PBE at worst.

He is triple overtuned. His Max% damage is THREE TIMES what a reasonable number would be. The scaling on it puts every other max hp scaling in the game to absolute shame.

So THAT is a straight up failure and it means people didnt do their job at all. Know what happens sometimes when people dont do their job? They get fired. Obviously, that is an overaction, but saying that balance team fucked up is absolutely correct this time.

That's how life is. If you do your job well, nobody notices because that is what's expected of you. If you do your job poorly, people notice that it was sub-par.

There are enough talented people in the world doing quality work in every field that there is now a baseline expectation for performance within your job beyond "You do well most of the time"

It's not necessarily justified or fair the amount of flak that the balance team receives, but in our modern consumerist western culture, people in general think that if it isn't perfect, the person is replaceable and the job can be done better.

Balance team is definitely under-appreciated and I'm not saying that it's fair to demand that others take their positions, I'm just saying it is an aspect of modern society that it is extremely unusual to actually receive praise for doing what's expected of you. You should be praised for doing well, and equally called out on your shortcomings (productive criticism though), but don't expect a free gold star for doing your job right. That would be nice, but at the moment that's not how the world works.
